metadata.case_name: Appellants v. Hubli Dharwar Municipal Corporation

facts.text: The respondent, Hubli Dharwar Municipal Corporation, originally constituted as a Borough under the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925, owned several buildings in Dharwar.
Some of these buildings were given on leases to the appellants in March and April 1953.
By General Committee Resolution No. 36 dated 29th June 1953, the Borough decided to recover house-tax and other municipal taxes from private individuals who were tenants of municipal buildings.
Notice issued by the President that all citizens in occupation of municipal buildings must pay taxes assessed.
Appellants preferred joint objections against levy of house-tax on 9th September 1953.
Government of Bombay sanctioned amendment to House-tax Rules on 9th September 1954.
General Committee passed Resolution on 19th February 1955 sanctioning levy of taxes on municipally owned buildings from 1st April 1955, with public notice.
Notice under section 77 published on 25th February 1955; taxes into force on 1st April 1955.
Fresh lease-deeds executed by respondent in favour of appellants on 11th May 1955; no mention of tenant liability for house-tax in original 1953 or fresh 1955 leases.
Bills issued to appellants for house-tax on leased buildings.
Appellants filed suit challenging legality of house-tax imposition, main ground that Municipality cannot impose house-tax on its own buildings; sued in representative capacity.
Respondent resisted suit claiming valid taxation and suit bad for want of notice under section 206-A.
Trial Court decreed suit: respondent not competent to levy excess over agreed rents; no notice under s.206A necessary.
First Appellate Court (Addl. District Judge) held levy not justified but suit not maintainable without notice u/s 206A; dismissed suit.
Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 888 of 1961 upheld dismissal: tax validly levied and suit not maintainable for want of notice u/s 206A; judgment dated 23 February 1966.

legal_issues.text: Whether a Municipality can impose house-tax on buildings owned by itself under the Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925.
Whether notice under section 206-A of the Act was necessary for the suit.

petitioner_arguments.text: Municipality cannot tax its own buildings, as per scheme of the Act; relied on provisions of ss.73,74,75,76,77,78,79,80,85.

respondent_arguments.text: Tax was validly levied; suit bad for failure to give notice under section 206-A.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of Act does not prohibit taxing own buildings; s.85 specifically envisages tax on buildings leased from municipality, primarily leviable from occupier.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Language of s.85 lays down tax leviable primarily from actual occupier even if holds on lease from municipality.

court_reasoning.text: Not anomalous as tax primarily on occupier, not owner; purpose to ensure payment by lessees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Imposition effective when building leased out.

court_reasoning.text: Agree with High Court that tax validly imposed; question of notice u/s 206A immaterial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In view of validity of tax, suit fails.

holdings.text: Municipality can impose house-tax on its own buildings under s.73, primarily leviable from occupier under s.85.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Municipal Boroughs Act, 1925
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to impose tax on buildings (s.73); primarily on occupier including lessees from municipality (s.85); procedure for imposition and notice (ss.75,77); suit notice requirement (s.206A)

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the High Court that the house-tax was validly imposed by the Municipality on its own buildings let out to tenants, and the suit challenging it failed.

key_quotes.text: "A tax imposed in the form of a rate on buildings or land or both shall be leviable primarily from the actual occupier of the property upon which the tax is assessed if he... holds it on a building... lease from... the municipality."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key statutory language supporting tax validity on municipal buildings leased out.

key_quotes.text: "The fixation of such responsibility primarily on the occupier holding a building on lease from the municipality could only be laid down on the basis that the buildings owned by the municipality can be subjected to the tax."
key_quotes.speaker: court
